4427907/4356575/4450832.title: Calls for Animals
4427907/4356575/4450832.text: hens - chuck chuckTurkeys - bee beeDucks - wheech wheechGeese - bathey batheySheep - shoven shovenCows - prigee prigeeCalves - suck suckass - preigh preighHorse - preigh preighPigs - furish furish deohde?Cats - sheemp sheemp

4428065/4374731/4461717.title: Calls for the Different Domestic Animals and Birds
4428065/4374731/4461717.text: Calls for the different domestic animals and birdsWhen calling ducks we say "wheech wheech".  When putting them away we say Shish  lach.When calling hens we say "chuck chuck".  When we are putting them away we say Shish cearch.When calling geese we say "bada bada".When putting them away we say Shish ge.When calling pigs we say "hurish hurish".When putting them away we say "muc muc".When calling the calves we say "suck".When putting them away we say "hi hi".Written by:- May Flynn, Ballymacredmond, Lahardane, Ballina, Co Mayo.

4428334/4396359/4486179.title: How Animals are Called
4428334/4396359/4486179.text:
Geese :- Leg a leg a leg a leg. (chasing them) goose, goose, goose, (when calling them).Turkeys :- Peep, peep, peep, peep.Duck :- Wheet, wheet, wheet, wheet.Hens :- tioc, tioc, tioc, tioc.Cows :- Té, té, té, té.It is a common custom for neighbours to swop "setting of eggs" to keep fowl virile & strong. The number of eggs "set" under animal depends on number the animal can conveniently cover. Duck eggs are often put under hens because they are better sitters and can cover more eggs.Unwanted "clocking" is cured by putting the affected animal under a creel and spilling water on it.



Usual type of churn is sketched opposite. [sketch of churn with measurements] Milk is kept in warm place until it thickens. When enough thick milk is gathered in large crockery basin it is put into churn. A lid with
(continues on next page)

4486410/4414681/4486495.title: Calls for Animals
4486410/4414681/4486495.text: Animals usually come for the name which you call to them. When we are putting out the cousin the morning we say "Tche". To the calf we say "Sugie". The goat is called "Panny", the sheep is called "Bess". The pig comes when we say "Hursh". To the hens we say "chuck" and to the birds we say, "Birdie". The turkeys come when we say "Peep Peep" and to the geese we say "goosie". We say to the ducks "tweet "tweet".Mary Magee,Broadpath, Convoy,Co Donegal

4498840/4385979/4512479.title: Calls for Animals
4498840/4385979/4512479.text:
Every animal answers to a call.Pigs usually answer to “joch joch”.Hens usually answer to “chuck chuck”. Cats usually answer to “puss puss”. Dogs answer to a whistle.Cows and calves answer to “suck suck”Sometimes goats answer to “here kitty”



When you are calling the ducks to feed them you say “weedy,widy,widy,widy,”When you are calling the turkeys you say “Bee-wee bee-wee bee-wee,”When you call the chickens you say “chick,chick,chick”

4498840/4385979/4512482.title: Calls for Animals
4498840/4385979/4512482.text:
Every animal answers to a call.Pigs usually answer to “joch joch”.Hens usually answer to “chuck chuck”. Cats usually answer to “puss puss”. Dogs answer to a whistle.Cows and calves answer to “suck suck”Sometimes goats answer to “here kitty”



When you are calling the ducks to feed them you say “weedy,widy,widy,widy,”When you are calling the turkeys you say “Bee-wee bee-wee bee-wee,”When you call the chickens you say “chick,chick,chick”

4569052/4567037/4574379.title: Calls of the Animals
4569052/4567037/4574379.text: In our place when they are calling the hens they say "tuk, tuk " and all the hens run for their food. When feeding ducks we say "spoon, spoon" and when calling geese we say  "laddy laddy". When calling turkeys people "Bee Bee". when calling cows home we say "prod prod" and they walk home.  When calling calves people say "suck, suck". When calling sheep we "thoo thoo". When calling pigs people say "thuck thuck". When calling goats we say "mag mag mag" we also say "gin gin". When selling eggs we always sprinkle holy water three times on them.

4583298/4577527/4586263.title: Farm Animals
4583298/4577527/4586263.text:
Cows are tied in cabins in several ways, some are tied by a rope round their horns attached to a post in the ground.Others by a chain round the neck which is fastened to a beam across the cabin inside which the hay is given to them.Others still are tied in "bales" which are made of timber posts stuck into the ground and the cow's head goes in between these posts and a block is stuck in at the top to keep the posts on the cow's neck.



Turkey's are called thus Beeb, beeb, Ducks Spoon, spoon, and Feenick, feenick.Hens Tuk, tuk.
(continues on next page)

4583327/4580096/4591375.title: (no title)
4583327/4580096/4591375.text:
When people are driving the cows they say "Sho" or "How". When calling the calves they say suck suck. The cows are tied with a chain to the manger. The chain is put round the cows neck and is then fastened to the manger. When people are calling hens they say chuck, chuck, when calling geese they say badthy, badthy, badthy. When the are calling the cat they say puish-urish and for the dog they whistle or call him by his name.



God bless Good Friday, Friday is the day. The day He carried His crown. With sharp thorns on his head which apears through his hands through his heart through his Blessed Mother looking on. With a heavy heart and a dismal cry anyone who says this prayer
(continues on next page)

4583293/4577066/4592635.title: Local Customs - Calling and Hunting Away Animals
4583293/4577066/4592635.text: Calling sheep,  "Tchown"Calling cow, "Twigeen"Calling calf, "Suck"Calling pig, "Furish"Calling horse, "Puwe"Calling Turkeys, "Yib"Calling Chickens, "Dyias"Calling Hens, "Chuck", "Tuk"Hunting away Ducks, "Sloh"Hunting away Hens, "Shull"Hunting away Cows, "How Out"Hunting away Geese, "Ske"Hunting away Chickens, "Shull"

4613698/4609913/4627896.title: An Chaoi a Glaoitear iad
4613698/4609913/4627896.text:
Is sean ainmeacha ó'n t-sean saoghal iad na h-ainmeacha a glaoidhtear ar na h-ainmeacha chun beatha. Nuair nachdtiocfadh na ba abhailetrathnóna teigheann duine de mhuinntir an tíghe ar thulach eicint agus deireann sé "Pró a bhó", agus mar a gcloisfeadh an bhó é deirfeadh sé, "Suicín, Suicín". "Sé an chaoi a thosnuigh síad ag fághail amach go dtuigfeadh an bhó é sin. Lá amháin chuaidh scata beidheathach go dtí áit a raibh póitín ga dheanamh agus bhí beirt sa teaichín agus breadhnuigh duine aca amach. Chonnaic sé ceann de na ba sínta ar taobh cnocáin. Glamdh sé ar an bhfear eile,. Nuair a chonnaic an fear eile í dubhairt sé, "is ar meisge ata sí ag an mbraith. Bhí na beidhthígh eile imthighthe scathamh taobh thiar dí. Ghlaoidh duine acú ortha agus th ainig siad ar ais. Dubhairt sé, "Pró a bhó." Bí raibh sé ag íarraidh na bhfocal sin a radh agus thuig na beidthígh é
(continues on next page)

4622990/4621499/4629398.title: Potatoes
4622990/4621499/4629398.text:
(continued from previous page)
"slit" is cut out of it for planting.Cuasán - the hole occasionally found in the centre of the large potato.



Calling animals and fowl.The following terms are used to call animals and flows.Cow: - Bet bet Pen PenPig: - Hurrish, hurris, Deoch, DeochCalf: - Suck suckHorse: - Peoch peochSheep: - Teón teón  Teo-theón Teo-theónDonkey: - Peoch, peochHens:- Tiuc, tiucGeese:- Deada, DeadaDucks: - Wheach, wheachChickens: - Dish, dish, Yish, yishTurkeys:- Yeeb, yeebGoats: - Yin yin

4701769/4701291/4727120.title: Calls Used to Animals and Fowl
4701769/4701291/4727120.text: To the cow, - "Pruggey pruggey", and "hursh"To the horse,- "Pcho"To the calves,- "Suck-suck-sucky".To the pigs,- "Hurris" -"deoch"To the sheep,- "Showey showey"To the goat- "Gabhair Gabhair"To a cat on the table- "Scat . Scut"To the hens- "Tuk Tuk"To the turkeys- "Yeb yeb"To the ducks-  "Wheet wheet"To the geese- "Bathey Bathey"To the chickens- "Chick Chick"

4713236/4710055/4728440.title: Common Calls for Animals at Home
4713236/4710055/4728440.text: 1. Person who gave the information:- Denis McCarthy.2. His address: Coom, Gneeveguilla Rathmore, Co. Kerry3. His age: 54 years4. Profession: Retired Policeman5. His age6. Name of school child who brought the information - Denis Moynihan7. His address- Coom, Gneeveguilla. Rathmore8. Age - 16 years.Common Calls for AnimalsFor Cows: -Sup, Sup, SupFor Sheep:- Suín, Suín, Suín.For Pigs:- Ban, Ban, and Hurrish, Hurrish,For Calves:- Suck, Suck, Suck.For Bulls: - Warra, Warra, Warra.For Dogs:- Sess, Sess, Sess.For Cats:- Pish, Wish, Wish.For Goats:- Pet, Pet, Pet.For Horses:- Filly, Fill, Fill.For Geese:- Badhie, Badhie, Badhie,For Ducks:- Feen, Feen, Feen.For Hens:-Tuck, Tuck, Tuck.For Chickens:-Chick, Chick, Chick.Denis MoynihanCoom Gneeveguilla15 years

4723854/4719296/4758919.title: Calls for Animals
4723854/4719296/4758919.text:
When people are calling animals home to the house they use different names. When they are calling the cows they say, "téigh, téigh". For the calves they say "sucky, sucky". For the pigs they say, "hurish, hurish", or "sty, sty". For the hens they say "tiochaidh, tiochaidh". For the turkeys they say "pee, pee". For the ducks they say "tweet, tweet". For the geese they say "sheleg, sheleg".We keep our cows in the byre at night in the winter time, but they stay out in the fields in summer. The cows are tied to a stake, with a chain around their necks. We clean the manure out of the byre every morning.Our horses are kept in the stable at night. They are tied with a rope to the manger. The stable is cleaned out every morning.



The people carry out many customs on different festivals. On Patrick's Day the
(continues on next page)

4723854/4719328/4759392.title: Potatoes
4723854/4719328/4759392.text:
My father sets potatoes every year. Some years he sets two acres. Others he sets one acre and a half. He does not set them in the same fields every year. He does not plough it all but he ploughs some of it and digs the rest. Uncle Dan had a wooden plough up to three years ago.



When people are calling calves they say, "Suchy Suchy". When they are callling goats they say, "Kiddy". When they are calling hens they say, "bhuchey". When calling cows they say "[?]". People say "P.P", when calling turkeys. When calling ducks they say "Whealie Wheat". When calling pigs they say, "Hurrish". People put a Benedict medal in the lyre in order to keep
(continues on next page)

4723854/4719352/4759506.title: Calls to Animals
4723854/4719352/4759506.text:
When the people are calling cows they say Téig.When calling calves they say "Suck suck"When calling the pigs they say "Hurish hurish"When calling the sheep they sau "Huitche"When calling hens they say "Tiocfaid" or "Birdie"When they are calling ducks they say "Pea pea"When they are calling geese, they say "Sheleg"When they are calling the goat, they say "Kiddy"When calling the cat they call "Pussy"When calling a dog they whistle or call "Cess"



The old people had pieces of broken pots which they called "cams". They put water in the cams and put the hard resin in it until it melted. Then they drained off the water when the resin would be quite soft. It was twisted round and round with a piece of stick to toughen it. They had strips of calico for wicks. They had to keep it warm in the can and take it out when it was soft. Then it was taken out and rolled on a stool with the two hands.

4701705/4694430/4760509.title: Calling Domestic Animals
4701705/4694430/4760509.text: The words used in this area are a mixture of English and Irish so I can only try to give them phonetically.Except for the call to the hens and pigs they have no meaning.CallingThe Cow - Prigín  The R is pronounced as if it were fry.The Pig: Hurrish, Hurrish also deoc! deoc!Horse and Donkey: Pu-seich! Pu-seich!The Dog: By name or to coax a dog a clacking noise is made by the tongue as when driving a donkey.The Cat: Pish! Pish and Sill! SillThe Hens: Tioc! Tioc! (means Come! Come!)The Ducks: Wheat! Wheat!The Geese: Bad-ie! Bad-ie!The Calves: Suck! Suck!The Turkey: Binn BinnDrivingThe Cow: Hursh! Hursh! also Howy! HowyThe Pig: Muc Amach! Muc Amach!Horse and Donkey: Go on! Go on! (G'wan, G'wan). Also driven by a clacking noise made by the tongue.The Cat: To frighten away a cat: Cuth! Cuth!The Hens: Cush! Cush!

4742165/4741253/4783453.title: (no title)
4742165/4741253/4783453.text:
(continued from previous page)
why the water runs off the duck's back when she gets wet.



A dead cock never crew.You might as well be out of the world as out of the fashion.



Calling a donkey they say "Peó Bess"



A man named Stapleton lived in Allenwood. Every night he used to go to play cards in some house in Kilpatrick. He had to leap a ditch every night. He was told not to go that way and not to leap the ditch. He took no heed and this night he stayed very late playing the cards. When he was up near the ditch he ran and jumped and jumped on a ghost. The ghost followed him and Stapleton got the priest and...
(continues on next page)

4758606/4758297/4785821.title: Words by which Domestic Animals and Fowl Are Called

4742024/4728946/4817595.title: Columcille's Prophesies
4742024/4728946/4817595.text:
(continued from previous page)
bayonet would stop them. One the second day they would be driven back.He also prophesied that Ireland would be ruled by a Spaniard.



On the river Deen there is a bridge. It is going over to the castle in the Demense.



You call the goat by the name "Jin".You call the pigeon by the name "polly".You call a hen by the
(continues on next page)

4742024/4728963/4817798.title: Games at Cross-Roads and at Certain Places
4742024/4728963/4817798.text:
(continued from previous page)
play games there such as skittles, meg, rings, darts, ludo, and all sorts of games like that.



You call a goat by saying "jin, jin, jin"You call a dog by saying "here, here, here"A calf by shaking a bucket.A horse by saying, "peo, peo, peo".hens by saying, "Cluck, Cluck, Cluck".An ass, "Bess, bess".Ducks, "Fin, Fin".A cat, "Puss, puss".

You call an ass by saying "Bess, Bess."you call a cat by saying "Puss, Puss"

4742024/4729040/4818107.title: Proverbs - "Kit Joyces Sacrament"
4742024/4729040/4818107.text:
(continued from previous page)
the lads would ask them to bring out "Kit Joyce's Sacrament".Hence Anything scanty or mean.



The following games are played at the country crossroads:- Skittles, Rings, Meg and Cards.



Paddles, Closhawn, Paddoc, The Sheep Hawk.



you call a calf by saying suck, suck.you call a foal by saying peo, peo.
(continues on next page)

4811586/4799359/4931188.title: The Care of the Fowl
4811586/4799359/4931188.text: The Care of the FowlWhen calling the hens he say "truc," "truc."When calling the geese we say "Badhee" "Badhee."When calling the ducks or their young we say "Whith" "Whith."The following folklore was given to me by my mother - Mrs. Mary K. Lough.

4921982/4915258/4943191.title: Áitainmneacha
4921982/4915258/4943191.school_info: School: Mount Collins, Mainistir na Féile

4921982/4915259/4943192.title: How People Call the Animals etc
4921982/4915259/4943192.text:
(continued from previous page)
kiddy (goats), pee pee (cows), Wurra (bull)



Chep; Rose; Tiny; Spot; Carlow; Bran; Bell; Bruno; Flossy; Prince; Jacko; Toby; Freddy; Teddy; Thricks; Daisy; Sally; Fly; Lally; Speed; Buff; Patsy; Rover; Jip; Beauty; Nell; Lass; Juno; Bagle; Pansy; Darky; Sandy; Sam; Speck;  Iwan; Fanny; Talma; Barny.

4922101/4852379/4948298.title: Farm-Yard Calls
4922101/4852379/4948298.text: There are many farm calls which we hear even in the Galtacht. If the bean an tíge wishes to call the hens she says "tuk, tuk, tuk". Or if she is calling the ducks she cries "feedy, feedy".Or again if she wants the calves to come to her, she cries "suc, suc". When she is calling the turkeys she cries "bia bia"[?] If the fear an tíge wishes the cows to come up to him he cries "tweh tweh".If he wants to hunt the pigs he says "hurish, hurish".If the cailín aimsire wishes to call the geese she says "bady, bady"Una O'Connell

4758509/4750284/4953468.title: The Care of the Farm Animals
4758509/4750284/4953468.text:
Cows, horses, pigs, and cattle are some of the farm animals, Some of the cows have got names, One of them is called the Polly another Madigans cow and another the Male cow."Ní, ní," is nearally always said when driving cows. The cow house is about twenty feet wide and forty feet long. The tyings are made with chain with a piece of an ioran in the wall. I dont know any customs about milking.



One or two horses are kept on every farm The horses are kept in stables, they eat hay, oats, and mangles and they drink water, they put the mangles and oats in a trock in the manger and put they hay down in the manger.



When calling the turkeys they say - "BB-BB-BB-BB."When calling ducks they say Finn Finn Finn"When calling chickens they say, "Chick chick."
(continues on next page)

4922232/4862844/5019364.title: Calls to Fowls
4922232/4862844/5019364.text: Geese "Gé Gé"Turkeys "Bee Bee"Ducks "Feeny Feeny"Hens "Tiuck Tiuck"Chicken  "Chick Chick"Calls to animalsCalves "Suck Suck"Asses "Cub Cub"Horses "Chep Chep" or "Phrigh Phrigh"Pigs "Bac Bac"Cats "Puss Puss"Goats "Tibby Tibby"Cows "Pooie Pooie"

4922258/4864947/5020985.title: Animal Calls
4922258/4864947/5020985.text:
Animal CallsCows: Pú-ín! Pú-ín! Pú-ínPigs: bach! bach! Bach!Ducks: fíní" fíní! fíní!Hens: Diuc! Diuc! Diuc!Geese: Párick! Parick! Parick!Turkeys: bí! bí! bí!Horse: Cóibí! Cóibí! Cóibí! Goat: Gin! Gin! Gin!Cat: Pish! Pish! Pish!Driving cows: How! How!Driving Horse: Hub off!  G'wan



Spade (Baisín)Rough drawing of type of spade called a "baisín" used for cutting "scraths" for fuel on mountain south of Newcastle. I saw them 40 years ago. I can't say are they in use now.See page 89 "baisín" in Parish of Grange.Diagram

4922246/4863991/5022115.title: Farm Animals and How Called
4922246/4863991/5022115.text:
The following are the farm animals and how they are called:Cows   "How"- "How"Calves  "Suck, Suck"Goats  "Gabair, Gabair"Pigs  "Boc, boc"Cats  "Push, push"Hens  "Tioc, tioc"Ducks  "Feedy, feedy"Geese  "Ge, ge"Turkeys "Bee, Bee"Chickens  "Chick, chick"When cows are brought home to be milked each walks into her own stall in the cow-house where she is tied by the neck with a  cord or a chain. This is  balled bailing the cows. If the cow is wicked or kicks during milking she is spancelled. This done by tying her hind legs together with a piece of cord. The milker usually whistles or sings while milking
(continues on next page)

4922240/4863632/5054408.title: Proverbs
4922240/4863632/5054408.text:
(continued from previous page)
Maire Cowan's lamentation. "Sorry too late". I am unable to say what circumstances give rise to this expression. "The day of the wind isn't the day of the scollop". "If you wrestle with a chimney sweep you'll get dirty."



Hens dyuk dyukChickens chick chickDuck Feedie feedieAss pshe psheHorse pshe psheCow pooee pooeeCalf suck suckGoat gin gin(pronounced jin jin)Turkey beeb beebGoose goosie goosie Cat puss puss

5008841/4960218/5073320.title: Animal Calls
5008841/4960218/5073320.text:
Hens - Chuck, chuck            or Juck Juck.Turkeys - Bee Bee Bee            or Bay Bay Bay             or Beep Beep Beep.Ducks - Wheet Wheet WheetPigs - Gush Gush GushCalves - Suck Suck SuckHorse - Hupia (up here)Young pigs are called "Gurries" and you say "Suck Suck" to them.Cattle - How HowDogs - Ciss ciss (setting them to fight)             Yeh yeh (calling them up)Chickens - Birdie Birdie BirdieCats -  Pish, wish wish wish            Ash cat.



Horses - Polly, Fanny, Kate, Nora, Billy, Lily
(continues on next page)

5008839/4960053/5077499.title: Calls for Domestic and Farm Animals
5008839/4960053/5077499.text:
In this great farming area there are many farmers' houses and around the latter there are many domestic and farm animals.The owners sometimes have trouble getting the animals to come for food and to avoid confusion they call each variety by a different call. The following is a list of the animals and the calls used by their owners when calling them for food:-Name - CallCow - Chee; Chee; Chee.Calf - Suckie; Suckie; Suckie.Cat - Pooish; Pooish; or Pussy; PussyHen - Juckie; Juckie; Juckie.Turkey - Bee; Bee; Bee (biadh)Chicken - Butchy; Butchy; Butchy.Duck - Weech; Weech; Weech.Goose - Goosey; Goosey; Goosey.Sow - Huraish; Huraish; Huraish.Bonham - Gorry; Gorry; Gorry.Dog - A whistle or Heah; Heah (here) or a sound like "click".Goat - Kiddie; Kiddie; Kiddie.Horse - Pshow; Pshow; Pshow.Donkey - There are few donkeys around but the usual sound is "come".
(continues on next page)

5044787/5038045/5083629.title: The Calls for the Various Kinds of Animals
5044787/5038045/5083629.text:
The calls for the various kinds of animals.Hens. '' Chuck chuck '' and '' Chuckie chuckie '' calls the hens to their feeding.Chickens :  Birdie BirdieDucks. '' Wheat Wheat '' and '' wheatie wheatie ''Geese. '' Leg Leg '' and to hunt them away '' Sh-leg, sh-leg ''Cows. '' Suck suck ''. They are also called by whistling for them or by shouting '' come on '' to them.Calves. They are called the same was as cows are called.Horse. The horse is a very responsive animal and will often come towards you if you say  '' come up here Bob '' etc. When driving the horse we say '' Go on 'our' that '', '' Get up ' our' that or a sound is often made by the mouth lick  '' jick, jick''. '' Ho there ''. '' Puree '' or      '' Stand up ''Ducks : - Young ducks are called by saying '' deedle deedle ''Turkeys : - '' Be Be '' is the call for turkeys.Dogs : - These are often called by whistling for them. They are often called by a sound resembling a kiss. This sound is also used in calling the horse.
(continues on next page)

5084100/5040730/5084496.title: (no title)
5084100/5040730/5084496.text:
When calling or driving animals or fowl we use different terms.When calling the hens we say "chucky, chucky". When calling turkeys we say "bee, bee". When calling chickens we say "birdie, birdie". We call the ducks by saying "wheety, wheety". When calling the cows we say "prugie, prugie". When driving the cows we say "hough, hough". When calling the pigs we say "hurish, hurish". When driving them we say "humuck, himuck". When calling the cat we say "pish, wish, wish". When calling the calves we say "suck, suck". When driving the donkey or horse we say "gee-up".The horse usually has a christian name. The dog also has a special name.Some people put a graip in
(continues on next page)

5084100/5040732/5084501.title: (no title)
5084100/5040732/5084501.text:
When we are driving or calling the animals and fowl we use different terms for them. When we are driving the cows we say "hough, hough". When calling the cows we say "prugie, prugie". When calling the hens we say "chuckie, chuckie". When we are calling the pigs we say "hurish, hurish". When calling the calves we say "suck, Suck".   When calling the chickens we say "birdie, birdie".  When calling the cat we sat "pish, wish".It is said if blessed palm is put up in the byre nothing happens to the cows. When there is a thunder storm a horse shoe or a piece of iron is put in the nest where
(continues on next page)

5084100/5040734/5084503.title: (no title)
5084100/5040734/5084503.text:
When driving or calling cows and fowl we use different terms for the different animals or fowl.When driving the cows we say "hough, hough" and when calling them we say "prugie, prugie". When calling the calves we say "suckie, suckie". When calling the pigs we say "hurish, hurish". When driving them we say "humuck, himuck".When calling the hens we say "chuckie, chuckie". When calling the chickens we say "birdie, birdie", When calling the ducks we say "wheet, wheet, wheet". When calling the cat we sat "pish, wish, wish."When a hen is hatching it is usual to place a horse shoe hanging on the side of the nest.
(continues on next page)

5044819/5041566/5084948.title: Our Horse
5044819/5041566/5084948.text:
He brings the turf home from the bog. He ploughs and harrows the ground. When we are bringing him home to the stable at night we call him by his name, and he stands for us to catch him. His colour is red. We clip him every winter.



There is place for one house in our stable. There is a manger and a ring for putting a rein in, to tie the horse with (The walls) We put the hay and oats in the manger. The walls are made of mud and stones and it is roofed with galvanize.



We have various ways for calling the animals.When calling the hens we say tiuc" tiuc"  The hen with chickens is called by saying "Cluck
(continues on next page)

5085281/5041142/5085482.title: Domestic Animals
5085281/5041142/5085482.text:
(continued from previous page)
his leg so that he cannot throw up his head. A kid is put with four or five calfs and it is that they thrive better.



There are many calls for animals and the calls for a pig is "Hurrish Hurrish". You call a goat by "Kiddy Kiddy" and you call a hen by "Tioc Tioc" You call a duck by "Wheat Wheat" and you call a turkey by "Peep Peep." You say "gosey" to run a  goose away from your house. The farmer says "Baa Bass" to call a sheep.



The following place names are the streets in Belturbet. Bridge St, Holborn Hill, Deanery St, Barrack Hill,  Main St, Diamond, Castle Hill, Church St, Chapel Rd., Martin's Row, St Mary's Terrace, Patrick St, William's St, Kilconny, Close, Widow's Houses, Water lane, Lawn, Fair Green, Mill Walk, Buttermilk bridge and the Slip
(continues on next page)

5070738/5058691/5092165.title: (no title)
5070738/5058691/5092165.text:
The word "lock" is in very common use here, as for instance - a LOCK of turf a LOCK of hay, and a LOCK of oats etc it is probably the Irish word GLAIC (glac coirce)A hollow potato - tube, etc is  said to be (BOAST) = empty in the heart.When a baby(?) laughs she is supposed to see angels.When night is falling the old people refer to this as - between the two lights.A certain water fowl swims just immediately below the surface of the water and the old people refer to this as swimming between the two waters



In calling fowl and domestic animals the old people had a particular call for each kind and these all knew their own calls."Phitongh, Phitongh" brought the mare galloping to her oats."Prug, Prug" coaxed the cow home to be milked"Suck Suckie brought the calf racing for her milk.
(continues on next page)

5070784/5063100/5095258.title: How People Call the Animals and Home Pets
5070784/5063100/5095258.text: How people call the animals and home pets.Horses are called by the word Pheó and when ploughing the men day to them Hup-Pheó, "Pway".  The call of the cow ("Pruggh") and if she is contrary when being milked they say to her Therish.Sheep are called by the word "moa" or "Mashy".Whe calling the cats peopls say Phish, Wish Wish.Pigs can be trained to come to their stye when called "Guh, Guhee, Guhee" The sow is called by the word"Hurish".  When controlling a dog from attacking anything people say "chew" or "chew dog"Hens will come when called by Cioc Cioc.  Turkeys know when called bíadh, bíadh.  Ducks are called by the word "wheet", wheet and chickens by "Buddee", "buddee" a slight change from the word Birdie.  Goats are called "Kiddy" Kidddy./  people call calves by the word Sucky, Sucky.  Often dogs are called "yeh","yeh"Charles SmithRahard, Lisduff,Kells,Co Meath

5070817/5067120/5097593.title: How Farm Animals and Birds Are Called in this District
5070817/5067120/5097593.text: muc: hunting the sow.hurais, hurais: calling the sowprought: catching the mare.hup: used in ploughingte: calling the cow.suck suck: calling the calves.circ: hunting the henstioc tioc: calling the hens.wheet wheet: calling the ducks.pee pee: calling the turkeys."Chew dog" is said to a barking dog to stop his barking.

5070831/5068539/5099043.title: Calls for the Various Animals
5070831/5068539/5099043.text: When calling cows the people say "Sug Sug" and when calling Calves they say "Suck Suck". When calling pigs they say "Gurrie Gurrie" and when calling sheep they say "Hetchie Hetchie. When calling the goats they say "Kiddie Kiddie". When calling hens they say "Tuic Tuic". When calling chickens they say "Birdie Birdie". When calling the ducks they say "Wheet Wheet". When calling Geese they say "Gleg Gleg" and when calling the turkeys they say "Pee Pee".

5070829/5068292/5099094.title: How We Call Our Animals
5070829/5068292/5099094.text:
When we want the hens we say "Chuck, Chuck". If we want the ducks we say "Wheet Wheet" and if we want the turkey we say "Beep, Beep" and if we want the pigs we say "Gurrie,"Gurrie" or "Hursh, Hursh". We say to the goats and kids, "Kiddy, "Kiddy"



People set thirteen eggs under a hen to hatch. The last one is supposed to be for luck. People put marks on the hatching eggs to know them. They put a mark with a pencil on them.



If a dog is barking, the usual way of making him lie down is to say "chew dog".

5070847/5069956/5099794.title: Old Story
5070847/5069956/5099794.text:
(continued from previous page)
by small horses about the size of dogs, along the lane. It was seen by many people. It is not known whether it went out the other end of the horse-shoe lane. Nobody followed it, because it is unlucky to follow anything strange like that.

5009138/4990476/5101410.title: Calls for Various Kinds of Animals and Birds
5009138/4990476/5101410.text: Calls for Various kinds of animals and birds. "Tuk Tuk" for calling hens"Weet Weet"  "  "  ducks"Yib Yib"        "   " turkeys"Badha Badha   "  " geese"Peo Pep"         "   " horse"Pruig Pruig"     "   " cow"Kiddy Kiddy"     "  " goatSuck Suck"       "  "  calves"Hurrish Hurrish"    "   " pigsCutch Cutch  for chasing cats"Hi mucks"       "      " pigs"Sea-lac"         "       "  ducks

5008921/4966723/5107372.title: Animal Calls
5008921/4966723/5107372.text:
Cows chains used to be made by Reilly's and Mullally's but are not made now.Animals Calls.Puis, puis to the cat. How-up when driving cows. Hurrish when calling pigs. Suck such when calves. Cioc cioc for hens. Wool was wound around cows "spins" and milk was suppossed to leave the cows and go to neighbour's cows after. After milking sign of Cross on cows udder - saying at same time God bless you. Marks on eggs hatching Names of children in household. Numbers to see which chicken comes out first. Dates on which eggs were laid.A small circle on each eggA cross put on eggs laid on Good Friday.They gather clodog at Easter around the countryIt is unlucky to keep a stray dog.Unlucky if changing house to bring the catA black cat following a child the child will die in seven days.As ass is lucky with mares in foal
(continues on next page)

5008925/4966989/5108683.title: The Calls for the Animals
5008925/4966989/5108683.text:
20-2-37 The calls made for the animalsThe call made for a hen is "chuck, chuck"The call for a duck is "weety, weety"The call for a chicken is "chick, chick"The call for a pig is "hurrish, hurrish"The call for a goat is "Jen, Jen"The call for a cat is "push, push" (Puisin, puisin")When hunting out the cat we say "cait, cait"When calling the cow say "prug, prug"When calling the calves home "suc, suc"



Story heard locally about an old woman who used to "take" the butter off the cows. There is an old story told in my parish that there was once an old witch living in it who used to turn herself into a hare and go around the field and suck the milk from the cows. One night the neighbours watched and they saw the hare running round the cows and they coursed her with dogs and after
(continues on next page)

5009018/4977700/5114817.title: How We Call
5009018/4977700/5114817.text:
The Sheep:(1) Mesh, Mesh, Mesh.(2) Choween, Choween, Choween.The Pigs:(1) Deoc, Deoc, Deoc.(1) Hurrish, Hurrish, Hurrish.(2) Spuck, Spuck, Spuck.The Cat:(1) Pshee, Pshee, Pshee.(1) Cait smac, Cait smcah, Cait smach.The Goats:(1) Minnie, Minnie, Kiddie, Kiddie,(2) Gabair, Gabair smach.
(continues on next page)

5009049/4981090/5116931.title: Cow Tyings
5009049/4981090/5116931.text:
Cows were tied up in the stables by means of 3 sticks which closed around the neak. These are still used in farmer places and are called, "Bails" Cows are addressed, "How," "How."



When cows are milked many people dip the finger in the milk and make sign of cross on the udder. In speaking of a cow, they always say, "God bless the cow."



Cow - "How", "How" in driving, "Pruggy," "Pruggy", in callingPig - "Hurrish," "Hurrish",Sheep - "Caoirigh", "Caoirigh", "Caoirigh".Cat - "Push" a, "wishe", "wishe," "wishe",Goat - "Gin," "Gin," "Gin,"Hens - "tioc", "tioc," "tioc,"Ducks - "weete", "weete," "weete",
(continues on next page)

5009126/4989121/5121031.title: Care of Animals
5009126/4989121/5121031.text:
(continued from previous page)
to the pig sty and say "Pig, Pig" take take the leicneac. You will be cured.  When a man buys pigs he has to get back luck-money-about sixpence a head.



Call for animalsTuk !  Tuk ! for hens.Bedda !  Bedda ! for geese.Suck !  Suck !  for calves.Beeb !  Beeb !  for turkeys.Hush !  Hush !  for pigs.Weet !  Weet !  for ducks.Prig !  Prig !  for cows.Peugh !  Peugh !  for horses.Gin !  Gin !  for goatsPish !  Wish  for cats.

5009117/4988286/5123309.title: Farmyard Calls Used Locally
5009117/4988286/5123309.text: For hens:- "Chuck - chuck"For ducks:- "Weety - weety"For turkeys:- "yib - yib"For geese:-  "a gay - gay - gay"For pigs:- "Hut - hut" or "hurush - hurush" For horses :- " Pruh - pruh"For cows:- "Prugh - prugh"Hunting bats :- "batch"calling goats:- "jin - jin"

5009108/4987366/5123602.title: Calls for Animals
5009108/4987366/5123602.text:
To call the cows home say "puoch home""  " horse home say prough here." "  pig say Huirish Huirish" "  calves " suck suck" " goat     " jinny jinny" "  hens   " tioch tioch" "  geese  " badaigh-badaigh" " turkeys " yib-yib" " ducks "   wheta-wheta" " cat "        puish-puish" " dog  "  clack here



You always put down thirteen eggs on a setting of duck or hen eggs. Three eggs are a setting of geese eggs. You put them down on a Friday night in the cupboard of the dresser. If there is thunder while hatching always put irons in the fire so that the noise will not kill the birds.Never lend a clocking hen. If you do the person who borrows must give you a penny.

5044640/5028349/5143932.title: The Call of the Animals
5044640/5028349/5143932.text:
The call of the animals 2-3-1938When we are clling the horse we say come Paddy. Suc. Suc. Suc. for the calves. Gin Chuck for the hens. Bac Bac. Bac. for the geese. Chuck. Chuck. Chuck. for the hens. Bac. Bac. for the pigs. Sib. Sib. for the cat. Be Be for the Turkeys. Puddle Puddle for the ducks. How How for the cows. Maa Maa for the sheep. Dec Dec for the dogs. Ba Ba for the lambs. Peup Peup for the ass. The foal fille fille.



Irish words 2-3-1938Cipini    are small sticksGabloig the fork of a treeA Vic      a sonMuise    an expression that people useCailin     a girl  AstorePuca      the puca Garsuin  a boyBr Br      calling the turkeySuimPrasosh  a weed that grows in the fieldAlanaBishog    a small river Laddie Mc Carthy. Rathenny. Cloughjordan.

4921598/4883258/5148492.title: Animals - Words Used for Calling or Driving Them
4921598/4883258/5148492.text:
ANIMALS - WORDS USED CALLING OR DRIVING THEMCows - how! how!. hi bo, gheabhais, wesh, ceartaig (said in the stall)calves - suck, suck: hí suckhorses - call 'filly filly" call his name 'Captain' Whee, gee up, go on Billy, settle over steady back, whoa, a click sound.Pigs - bain, bain or a sucking sound or [?]goats - kiddy kiddy, or call name, Hi agabhair, hí sgeabhairhens - tuck, tuck, hi cearcducks - feen feenGeese - call badhy, badhy, hi géturkeys - call peen, peen or fee feedog - call 'pup, pup', [?]  , hullas.Cat -- pus, pus, ciur out



We have a breachy (or brachy) cow at home. She is well known for her breaching. One day she is in the meadow; another day she is in the turnips and so in this way we have a job with her.   The other day we got
(continues on next page)
4921598/4883258/5148492.school_info: School: Doirín Árd, Béal Átha an Dá Chab

4921660/4888380/5152459.title: Names of Animals
4921660/4888380/5152459.text:
We have names on all our cows such as dearg means red we have two red cows and we called one of the Reddie. Purty is the name of a red and white cow.Rose is the name of a black or blue cow. Dandy is the name of a red and white cow. she is very quiet and we called her Dandy. Dolly is the name of a white and brown cow.



Calling the cows-how how or sup supcalling the calves-souk soukcalling the sow hurish hurishcalling the bonnives-bane baneCalling the fowlcalling the hens- tuck-tuckcalling the turkeys-tee-teecalling the ducks-feen-feen
(continues on next page)

4921660/4888418/5152570.title: Robbery and Murder
4921660/4888418/5152570.text:
(continued from previous page)
home to bury him and they buried him in Johny Crowley's glen



Bluebell, Blossom, Daisy, Strawberry, Blackey, Molly, Purty, Cully.



Calling the hens we say-tuck-tuckCalling the calves suck-suckCalling the goats meg-megCalling the donkey twee-tweeCalling the bonnives bon-bonCalling the geese baddy-baddy-baddyKitty FlynnMuckrossClonakilty

4921697/4890946/5153658.title: Calling to Animals
4921697/4890946/5153658.text: Driving the cows we say: habha habha habha or ha-bhaCalling the cows: sop sop sopCalling calves: suc suc suc (and give finger to suck)Calling pigs: thuiris thuiris hurrais hurraisCalling bonhams: ban ban banCalling hens: tioc tioc tiocCalling ducks: fín fín fínCalling the cat: puis puisDriving the horse: hupStopping horse: bhaoiDriving off the cat: cuit cuit'Cuit a chait ó'n obair sinNí h-ort a bheadh sé ach orm-sa'Said nurse to cat drinking the child's milk

4921631/4886471/5164084.title: Cattle Calls etc
4921631/4886471/5164084.text:
Cattle Calls etc. (Current usage)--------------------------------------Driving Cows:--------------------How-how!Hush!  Hi bó-----------Calling -Sup sup sup-!------------------------Driving or "shoo-ing off" a cow:--------------------------------------------Cuitsha! Cuitsha 'mach as so!Calling :- Hurrish hurrish !------------------------------
(continues on next page)

4921893/4899210/5182075.title: Money
4921893/4899210/5182075.text:
(continued from previous page)
Going to school long ago we used to have what we considered a very smart question to put to a new boy. We used to ask him to read "1/6 & I went into the 5/= Hotel to dine on the 1d of a bird". : - The translation being Bob Tanner and I went into the Crown Hotel to dine on the wing of a bird."



1. Calling calves to the drinking vessel - "Sook, sook, sook! [pronounced like] Look, look, look.2. Calling ducks to prepared food - Feen, feen, feen [pronounced like pín].3. Calling hens. "Tuk, tuk, tuk" or Took, took, took." Also "Tookie, Tookie, Tookie". 4. Driving in animals, geese, hens, etc to their sleeping quarters - "Hullah isteach" or Hull isteach". Seems to be connected with "cosla"[?] sleep.5. Setting a dog off on a chase after sheep or other animals -  "Hulla-hull": pronounced like "full".6. Saying "get out of it" to a pig - "Cuirseas" nó [?]
(continues on next page)
4921893/4899210/5182075.school_info: School: Convent of Mercy, An Pasáiste, Corcaigh

4921728/4894159/5187769.title: The Following Words Are Used Locally when Calling Our Domestic Animals
4921728/4894159/5187769.text:
1. Calves. 'suc - suc - suc' --- 'suc - suc - suc' --- 'suc - suc - suc'.2. Cows. 'huf - huf - huf' and also 'suc - suc - suc' as for calves. When driving the cows:- 'how - how - how'.3. Horse - foal etc. 'filly - filly - filly'.4. Pig. hurrais - hurrais - hurrais.5. banbh. ban - ban - ban. (When driving away pigs or 'banbhs' 'cud-gha out 'that.)6. Hens. 'tuc - tuc - tuc' --- 'tuc - tuc - tuc' --- 'tuc - tuc - tuc'.7. Chickens. 'sic - sic - sic'  ------8. Ducks. 'fín - fín - fín' and 'Fíní - Fíní - Fíní'9. Geese. 'beadaí - beadaí - beadaí'10. Turkeys. 'bí - bí - bí' -----11. Goat. mé - hé - hé, mé - hé - hé etc.12. Sheep. Báh - Báh - ha - ha -----lambs are often called like goats.13. Dog. 'Pup - pup - pup' or usually by its proper name. The following are some local names of dogs:- Shep. Buff. Dingo. Lass. Prince. Rose. Rex. Swank.In this locality milch cows are housed at night from the end of October or early in November until May 20th of the following year. The cattle must be 'kept-in' for such a long period because the cold & wet of winter set in early and the cold of spring prevents the
(continues on next page)

5162119/5155707/5196500.title: Calling the Animals
5162119/5155707/5196500.text: We say "Phew Phew Phew" when calling the horse. We say "Poohey, Poohey, Poohey" when calling the cows. We say "Suck, Suck, Suck" when calling the calves. We say "Bac, Bac, Bac" when calling the pigs. We say "Mah, Mah, Mah" when calling the sheep. We say "Here, Here, Here" when calling the dog. We say "Sib, Sib, Sib" when calling the cat. We say "Jen, Jen, Jen" when calling the goat. We say "Geg, Geg, Geg" when calling the geese. We say "Tioc, Tioc, Tioc" when calling the hens. We say "Feady, Feady, Feady" when calling the ducks. When the animals hear these various calls they know they are called to their food, and they run to it at once.

5177630/5174369/5201220.title: Ways of Calling and Driving Animals in this Part of the Country
5177630/5174369/5201220.text: 319Ways of Calling and Driving Animals in this part of the country.Horses :- "Phew Phew"(to call)Cow:- "Pwhee Pwhwee"(to call)      "habha habha" when driving."deisia"to get the cow in position for milking."éirigh"(to get the cow standing)The "Riabhac cow" name of a cow.Goat ;-"Gin Gin"   (to call)      "Hurra Gabhar"( in driving)     Pig:- "Deoch deoch" (to call)        "Hurra much"(in driving)Sow :-"Hurush Hurush"(to call)Hens:- "TiucTiuc" (to call)     " Hurra chirc"(in driving) Chickens:-"Coody coody"(to call)Turkey "Bee Bee"(to call)geese "Badhy badhy" (to call)"Hurra Gé Hurra Gé"(in driving)Ducks:- Feed Feed"(to call)

When calling hens I say "Tuk, Tuk, For ducks I say "Bathy, Bathy," For Turkeys I say "Beeb Beeb."  For chickens I say "Chick, Chick." When calling pigs I say "Hourish." For calves I say "Suck, Suck. For cows I say "Pruig, Pruig or

When calling hens I say, "Tuk, Tuk," For ducks, I say "Slogh" "Slogh". For geese,  "Bathy, Bathy,". For Turkeys I say "Beeb Beeb." For chickens I say "Chick, Chick."When calling pigs I say "Hourish." For calves I say "Suck, Suck. For

5215809/5231339/5263326.title: Calling Up the Dead
5215809/5231339/5263326.text: Calling up the dead.One night a man said he would pass a graveyard and call all the ghosts out. He passed the graveyard at about twelve o clock as he said he would. About a million of small things arose from under the stones with white sheets on their heads which ran beside the graveyard. There was a river on the other side of the road and hte man was flung into the river and drowned. I heard this story from Sarah Kerrigan, Knappa-Beg Westport

4921689/4890147/5278387.title: Names of Cows
4921689/4890147/5278387.text:
Dandy, Strawberry, Rose, Purty,Spot, Brindle, Lady, Kitty, Kerry,White cow, Red cow, Blue cow, Smólach,Bluebell, Curl, Cocked horn, Polly,Bessie, Blackie, Gracie, Starry, MasonMagpie, Lily, Adhairchín, Queenie,Maol, Daisy.



The following are the ways of calling the animals and fowlHens — Tuck, Tuck, Tuck.Ducks — Feen, Feen, Feen.Turkeys. — Tee, Tee, Tee.Geese — Baid, Baid, Baid.Cows. — Sup, Sup, Sup.Calves. — Suck, Suck, Suck.Pigs. — Hurish, Hurish, Hurish.bonhams. Bain, Bain, Bain.Dogs. — by name – Rex. Beauty.Horses — by name – Bill, Kitty.Donkeys. — Come on.Goats. — Bet, Bet, Bet.Sheep. — Shune, Shune, Shune.The following are the ways to drive away the animals and fowl –Cows. — How, How, How.
